Lately work has been done on renaming parts of the API to establish a common pattern (e.g. #36798, #36734), and a common pattern is well-defined in `:help dev-api-name`:

```
Use this format to name new RPC |API| functions: >
    nvim_{topic}_{verb}_{arbitrary-qualifiers}

Do not add new nvim_buf/nvim_win/nvim_tabpage APIs, unless you are certain the
concept will NEVER be applied to more than one "scope". That is, {topic}
should be the TOPIC ("ns", "extmark", "option", â€¦) that acts on the scope(s)
(buf/win/tabpage/global), it should NOT be the scope. Instead the scope should
be a parameter (typically manifest as mutually-exclusive buf/win/â€¦ flags like
|nvim_get_option_value()|, or less commonly as a `scope: string` field like
|nvim_get_option_info2()|).
```

So I thought it could be useful to have a full overview of the state of current API function names. I'm **not** advocating that every single one of them _should_ change or that my suggestions are the right approach. This merely lists which function names comply to the convention and which don't.

I've split the functions in their current "categories" or scopes. Each function has a label (legend below) and a suggestion for the change to comply with the convention.

Legend:
- âœ…: Name follows pattern
- â”: Not sure / doesn't have to follow the pattern
- â›“ï¸â€ğŸ’¥: Needs decoupling from scope (`nvim_buf_get_keymap` --> `nvim_get_keymap` with a scope argument)
- âš ï¸: Needs rename, but not a signature change (i.e. `nvim_buf_delete` --> `nvim_buf_del`)
- âŒ: Needs a rename and change in signature (i.e. `nvim_list_wins` --> `nvim_win_get`)
